questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath for 1 month. Initially, he was able to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment, but he now needs several breaks to catch his breath. He has no chest pain. He has rheumatic heart disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He emigrated from India about 25 years ago. His current medications include carvedilol, torsemide, and insulin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows bilateral crackles at the lung bases. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Echocardiography shows no valvular calcifications, atrial clots, or atrioventricular regurgitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve repair is indicated for symptomatic or severe aortic valve disease. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease. Both aortic regurgitation (AR) and aortic stenosis (AS) can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, unlike this patient's murmur, AR causes a blowing early diastolic murmur heard best at the left midsternal border and AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of aortic regurgitation

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged. The left ventricle, ascending aorta, and aortic arch are prominent as a result of dilatation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve replacement is indicated for patients with mitral valve stenosis who are not candidates for the first-line treatment. Although mitral replacement is a potential treatment for this patient's mitral valve stenosis, replacement would require open surgery that is associated with considerable morbidity and mortality. Other less invasive treatment options would be preferred, as they offer similar symptomatic improvement with lower risk.

C) CORRECT:

Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC) is the treatment of choice for many cases of symptomatic mitral stenosis because it improves valve function and symptoms, is less invasive, and the morbidity and mortality rates are lower than with other surgical treatment options. This patient has a favorable valve morphology (no calcifications) and no evidence of a left atrial thrombus or mitral regurgitation, which makes him a good candidate for PMBC. If the patient's echocardiography were less benign, open valvular replacement would be indicated.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

D) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is the treatment of choice for most cases of symptomatic or severe aortic stenosis (AS) in patients who are not suited to surgery. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease, with AS being less common than aortic regurgitation. AS can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin therapy would be indicated if this patient had evidence of atrial fibrillation (e.g., irregular heart rhythm), evidence of left atrial thrombus (e.g., echocardiographic finding or embolic stroke), or a mechanical heart valve. Although this patient is at risk for all of these conditions given his mitral valve stenosis and may require warfarin in the future, there is no clear indication for warfarin at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) are indicated for patients with heart failure because they have been shown to reduce mortality (likely via aldosterone reduction, which decreases myocardial remodeling, among other mechanisms). Although this patient has symptoms of heart failure, ACE inhibitors (and other afterload reduction agents) are contraindicated in mitral valve stenosis, which decreases the preload available for the left ventricle to pump into the systemic circulation, meaning that the ability to maintain perfusion of vital organs is already compromised. If the ability of peripheral arteries to constrict is downregulated (e.g., by an ACE inhibitor), then perfusion may be insufficient and end-organ damage may occur.
questions.hint: A low-pitched diastolic murmur with an opening snap in a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease is characteristic of mitral valve stenosis. These findings in combination with exertional dyspnea and bibasilar crackles without chest pain indicate cardiogenic pulmonary edema and heart failure due to valvular disease.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 2 episodes of loss of consciousness over the past week. She recovered immediately and was not confused following the episodes. During the past 5 months, she has also had increased shortness of breath and palpitations. She has been unable to carry out her daily activities. She also reports some chest tightness that resolves with rest. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She immigrated with her family from India 10 years ago. Her temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 115/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows accentuation and splitting of S2. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur in the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these findings?

choices.text: Increased left ventricular end diastolic pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) is seen in left heart failure, but this patient demonstrates signs of mitral stenosis (MS). MS causes a decrease in LVEDP due to impaired ability to fill the left ventricle in diastole through the stenotic valve.

B) INCORRECT:

Left-to-right shunting may be present in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) or an atrial septal defect (ASD). However, this patient's cardiovascular examination is consistent with mitral stenosis (opening snap with low-pitched diastolic murmur at the apex). She does not have a murmur that suggests a VSD or ASD (holosystolic murmur).

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased left ventricular contractility may be due to ischemic or nonischemic cardiomyopathy. A decrease in contractility may lead to left heart failure, increased left heart pressures, and subsequent right heart failure. However, the patient shows signs of mitral stenosis (MS), left atrial dilatation, and right ventricular hypertrophy, suggesting that MS is the underlying mechanism and not left ventricular failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased systemic arterial resistance can be seen in patients with essential hypertension or secondary causes of hypertension. This may eventually lead to left ventricular hypertrophy which can evolve into diastolic dysfunction. As this patient shows right axis deviation on ECG, she is unlikely to have left ventricular hypertrophy. Additionally, the patient has normal blood pressure on examination, which suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Preload to the right ventricle is determined by central venous pressure and venous return to the heart and may be increased in states that expand blood volume (such as congestive heart failure). While this patient shows signs of right-sided heart failure, the presence of mitral stenosis with right axis deviation suggests a different underlying mechanism of the patient's disease.

F) CORRECT:

Mitral stenosis leads to increased left atrial pressure, causing both left atrial dilatation, which may result in atrial fibrillation, and an increase in pulmonary arterial pressure to overcome the increased left heart pressure (pulmonary hypertension). Over time, this will lead to pulmonary vascular remodeling, increased pulmonary vascular resistance, splitting of S2, and right ventricular hypertrophy (as indicated by the right axis deviation) to compensate. Right ventricular failure eventually manifests with characteristic features such as jugular venous distention and pitting edema.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.
questions.hint: This patient has features of mitral stenosis (opening snap and diastolic murmur along with atrial fibrillation) that has progressed and caused further hemodynamic changes. Mitral stenosis commonly occurs as a late complication of rheumatic fever, which is more common in developing countries where patients may not have been adequately treated.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of shortness of breath while lying on her back over the past month. During this period, she has also had several episodes of bloody coughing. The patient reports that she had a heart problem when she was a child that was treated with antibiotics. She emigrated to the US from Russia 5 years ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. An ECG shows tachycardia and no P waves. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation may be caused by pulmonary hypertension as a result of volume overload in patients with left-sided heart failure. Such patients would present with signs of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which would explain this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. However, pulmonary regurgitation causes a diastolic murmur heard best at the second left intercostal space parasternally (sometimes referred to as Graham Steel murmur), which would be more pronounced during inspiration.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Although severe aortic valve stenosis may eventually cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), patients would most likely first present with syncope or angina. Furthermore, aortic stenosis causes a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space, which can radiate to the carotids.
Image Description:

Aortic stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the aortic valve to completely open during systole, impeding blood from flowing from the left ventricle to the aorta during systole. This generates in a harsh mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope in the right 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area). The murmur characteristically radiates to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in developed countries and is often caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is usually asymptomatic and is best heard at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line as a high-frequency mid-to-late systolic murmur with a mid-systolic click.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis is usually congenital and causes a systolic murmur best heard at the second left intercostal space parasternally. It can radiate to the back and also be present as a widely split second heart sound, which is not consistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles). However, it manifests as a holosystolic murmur (i.e., audible between S1 and S2) best heard at the apex of the fifth left intercostal space, in contrast to this patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2).
Image Description:

Mitral regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the mitral valve to completely close at the end of diastole, causing a retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole. This results in a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries but may radiate to the axilla. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2) at the fifth left intercostal space and opening snap indicate mitral valve stenosis, which causes an increase in left atrial pressure (and increased pulmonary wedge pressure) and a backup of blood into the lungs. Volume overload eventually causes symptoms of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which explains this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. The absence of P waves confirms atrial fibrillation, a common complication of mitral stenosis. This patient most likely suffered from rheumatic fever, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve stenosis is extremely rare and can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it causes a diastolic murmur best heard at the left fourth intercostal space parasternally and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo

H) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is best heard as a systolic murmur at the fourth intercostal space parallel to the sternum and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the tricuspid valve to completely close at the end of diastole, thus causing a retrograde flow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole. This generates a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the left lower sternal border. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

I) INCORRECT:

Although aortic regurgitation may lead to signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), it causes a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best parasternally at the second intercostal space, and may sometimes be accompanied by an Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Aortic regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the aortic valve to completely close at the end of systole, allowing a retrograde flow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This generates an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area) and/or at the right 3rd intercostal space (i.e., Erb point). The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.
questions.hint: This patient's heart problem is consistent with a history of rheumatic fever. An x-ray of the chest in this patient would likely show left atrial enlargement as a result of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening fatigue and shortness of breath. Her symptoms began 8 months ago and have progressively worsened since then. She had recurrent episodes of joint pain and fever during childhood. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She emigrated from the Congo with her parents when she was 12 years old. Her temperature is 37.4째C (99.3째F), pulse is 90/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. There is an opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space in the midclavicular line. If left untreated, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nephritic syndrome due to poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune-complex mediated complication of streptococcal infection. This patient, who has rheumatic heart disease, has most certainly had a streptococcal infection during childhood or early adolescence. However, PSGN occurs within 16 weeks of streptococcal infection in the same age group; it would not occur in adulthood.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinal vein occlusion is a complication of systemic disease such as atherosclerosis, diabetes mellitus, and vasculitis, and is also seen in patients with hypercoagulable states (e.g., polycythemia vera, sickle cell disease, oral contraceptive use). Patients with mitral stenosis and concurrent atrial fibrillation due to an enlarged left atrium are at increased risk of retinal artery occlusion secondary to embolization from the atria.

C) CORRECT:

Long-standing mitral stenosis can lead to an enlarged left atrium due to chronically elevated left atrial pressures. In some patients, the atrium may become so massively enlarged that it can compress the esophagus. In only very rare cases do patients develop esophageal compression that is severe enough to cause dysphagia (dysphagia megalatriensis).

Other rare complications associated with massive enlargement of the left atrium include recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy (Ortner syndrome) and massive hemoptysis due to erosion of the bronchial arteries.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A convexity between the moguls produced by the main pulmonary artery (PA) and left ventricle (LV) suggests enlargement of the left atrial appendage (LAA; normal configuration indicated by dashed line). Breast shadow opacification (green overlay) simulates parenchymal airspace disease.

AA: aortic arch

D) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal bleeding from angiodysplasia in patients with aortic stenosis (AS) has been called Heyde syndrome. AS can occur in rheumatic heart disease and cause dyspnea. However, AS would cause a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is best heard at the upper sternal borders, and an opening snap would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) is associated most commonly with chronic hypertension and aortic stenosis. Patients with untreated, severe mitral stenosis are instead at increased risk of developing right ventricular hypertrophy due to pulmonary artery hypertension (from high left atrial pressures). The presence of an opening snap in this patient is suggestive of mitral stenosis, of which LVH is not a common complication.

F) INCORRECT:

Ventricular tachycardia is a serious type of arrhythmia that arises from the ventricle. Patients with mitral stenosis due to rheumatic heart disease are more likely to develop supraventricular tachyarrhythmia such as atrial fibrillation due to atrial enlargement.
Image Description:

ECG (paper speed: 25mm/s):

Broad, monomorphic QRS complexes with a ventricular rate of approx. 176/min.
Because of the high ventricular rate, P waves and T waves are not visible (fusion complexes). The oscillations seen in the 2nd complexes in II and III are due to artifact.
The rapid ventricular rate and the abnormal morphology makes the evaluation of axis and intervals irrelevant.

Diagnosis: monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.
questions.hint: The patient's clinical features indicate progressive mitral stenosis. The most common cause of mitral stenosis in a young adult is rheumatic heart disease (RHD), which usually develops 1030 years after one or more episodes of rheumatic fever. Rheumatic fever occurs during childhood following streptococcal pharyngitis and is characterized by fever and joint pain. A history of immigration from a developing country is an important risk factor for RHD.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the office because of 4 episodes of loss of consciousness over the past 2 weeks. She recovered immediately and was not confused following the episodes. For the past 6 months, she has also had increased shortness of breath, palpitations, and chest tightness that resolves with rest. She immigrated with her family from India 10 years ago. Pulse is 115/min and irregular and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows an accentuated and split S2. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur in the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these findings?

choices.text: Increased oxygenated blood in the right ventricle
Increased left ventricular end diastolic pressure

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mitral stenosis leads to elevated left atrial pressure, which can trigger atrial fibrillation and cause increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP). Over time, the increased PCWP leads to remodeling of the pulmonary arteries, increased pulmonary vascular resistance, an S2 split, and right ventricular hypertrophy (seen as right axis deviation). In MS, shorter interval between the opening snap and S2 indicates more severe disease. This is because left atrial pressure is greater than left ventricular end-diastolic pressure.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Central venous pressure (preload) is a marker of venous return to the heart and may be increased in states that expand blood volume (e.g., congestive heart failure, intravenous fluid administration). While this patient shows signs of right-sided heart failure, the presence of mitral stenosis with right axis deviation suggests a different underlying mechanism of the patient's disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased oxygenated blood in the right ventricle may be present in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) or an atrial septal defect (ASD) due to left-to-right shunting. However, this patient's cardiovascular examination is consistent with mitral stenosis (opening snap with low-pitched diastolic murmur at the apex). She does not have a murmur that suggests a VSD or ASD (holosystolic murmur).

D) INCORRECT:

Increased mean arterial pressure can be seen in patients with essential hypertension or secondary causes of hypertension. This may eventually lead to left ventricular hypertrophy which can evolve into diastolic dysfunction. As this patient shows right axis deviation on ECG, she is unlikely to have LV hypertrophy. In addition, the patient has normal blood pressure on examination, which suggests a different diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased left ventricular end diastolic pressure (LVEDP) is seen in left heart failure, but this patient demonstrates signs of mitral stenosis (MS). MS causes a decrease in LVEDP due to impaired ability to fill the LV in diastole through the stenotic valve.
questions.hint: This patient has features of mitral stenosis (opening snap and diastolic murmur along with atrial fibrillation) that has progressed and caused further hemodynamic changes. MS commonly occurs as a late complication of rheumatic fever, which is more common in developing countries where patients may not have been adequately treated.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations. She has a history of recurrent episodes of joint pain and fever during childhood. She emigrated from India with her parents when she was 10 years old. Cardiac examination shows an opening snap followed by a late diastolic rumble, which is best heard at the fifth intercostal space in the left midclavicular line. This patient is at greatest risk for compression of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The trachea terminates by bifurcating into the right and left bronchi superior to the left atrium. Therefore, cardiac compression of the trachea is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

The thoracic duct lies in the posterior mediastinum and is separated from the heart by the descending thoracic aorta and the esophagus. It is therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement.

C) INCORRECT:

The vagus nerves lie posterior to the hila of the lungs bilaterally. They are therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement. In rare cases, compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve by a significantly enlarged left atrium may occur in patients with chronic mitral stenosis. Patients may then present with hoarseness of voice.

D) INCORRECT:

The hemiazygos vein lies in the posterior mediastinum, which is separated from the heart by the descending thoracic aorta and the esophagus. It is therefore unlikely to be compressed by cardiac enlargement.

E) CORRECT:

Because the posterior mediastinal portion of the esophagus lies just behind the left atrium, it is at risk of being compressed and/or displaced by an enlarged left atrium. Left atrial enlargement due to increased left atrial pressure can develop in patients with chronic mitral stenosis, although this occurs very rarely.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur is characteristic of mitral stenosis, which, given her immigration history and recurrent fever and joint pain, is most likely secondary to rheumatic fever. Untreated chronic mitral stenosis results in left atrium dilation, which can compress adjacent structures.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressively worsening dyspnea, cough, and hoarseness of voice. Her pulse is 92/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a rumbling mid-diastolic murmur that is best heard at the apex in the left lateral decubitus position. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral annular calcification, when severe, can cause mitral stenosis as a result of impaired diastolic dilation and restriction of valve motion. However, this condition typically affects older adults (> 50 years of age) and is usually asymptomatic; it is not a likely cause of this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration with pathological weakening of valvular connective tissue results in mitral valve prolapse (MVP), which can manifest with features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, cough) and a murmur that is best heard at the mitral area (cardiac apex). Left atrial enlargement due to chronic MVP can cause atrial fibrillation and hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve compression. However, unlike this patient's diastolic murmur, MVP is characterized by a late systolic crescendo murmur with a mid-systolic click due to sudden tensing of the chordae tendinae.

C) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis can cause a murmur at the cardiac apex due to mitral valve involvement, and it can also cause clinical features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, cough). However, the murmur is caused by mitral regurgitation and would, therefore, be systolic rather than diastolic; infective endocarditis is very rarely associated with mitral stenosis. Moreover, this condition is not associated with hoarseness of voice.

D) CORRECT:

Rheumatic heart disease is by far the most common cause of mitral stenosis. Following infection by group A streptococci, patients can develop rheumatic fever, in which cross-reactivity of streptococcal M protein antibodies with similar heart valve proteins may occur. This triggers an inflammatory process that results in valvular fibrosis, scarring, and narrowing. Symptoms of mitral stenosis include fatigue, exertional dyspnea, cough, and atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular pulse). Hoarseness can develop in severe cases because of left atrial enlargement and compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve (Ortner syndrome).
Image Description:

Diastolic murmurs (orange waveform) occur in:

(A) Mitral stenosis (decrescendo murmur with OS)
(B) Tricuspid stenosis (mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur)
(C) Patent ductus arteriosus (continuous crescendo-decrescendo murmur)
(D) Aortic and pulmonary regurgitation (decrescendo murmur)

Note that patent ductus arteriosus produces a continuous murmur heard in both systole and diastole.

OS: opening snap

E) INCORRECT:

Sarcomeric gene mutations underlie hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which can manifest in young adults with features of heart failure (e.g., dyspnea, cough) and a murmur (due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction). HCM is also a risk factor for the development of atrial fibrillation. However, the murmur associated with HCM is a systolic ejection murmur (crescendo-decrescendo murmur) that is best heard at the left sternal border. Moreover, HCM is not associated with hoarseness of voice.

F) INCORRECT:

Congenital valvular defects only very rarely cause mitral stenosis, accounting for approx. 1% of all cases, and are usually present in children; it is not a likely cause of this patient's condition.
questions.hint: The rumbling mid-diastolic murmur at the apex is characteristic of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of shortness of breath with exertion. He immigrated to the United States from Ghana 20 years ago. His pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Echocardiography shows thickened mitral valve leaflets with reduced motion and a narrowed mitral valve orifice diameter. Which of the following auscultation findings is most likely to correlate with the severity of this patient's valvular disease?

choices.text: Decreased time between S2 and opening snap
Radiation of murmur to the axilla

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased time between the aortic component of S2 and the opening snap (OS) occurs due to increasing left atrial pressure (LAP) brought on by worsening MS. The greater the LAP, the faster the acceleration of valve leaflets to the maximal point of opening, and the sooner the opening snap occurs after S2. The most common cause of MS in developing countries is rheumatic fever.

Atrial fibrillation and pulmonary hypertension are also associated with poor prognosis in patients with MS.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

B) INCORRECT:

The presence of a mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur is associated with mitral valve prolapse. The click occurs as the chordae tendinae anchoring the prolapsed valve leaflet reach their maximum length and snap tight. However, this patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis, which does not manifest with a mid-systolic click.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation of a murmur to the axilla is most noticeable in mitral regurgitation. However, this patient's echocardiography is consistent with mitral stenosis, which is best heard from the apex and is not known to radiate.

D) INCORRECT:

An increased intensity of a murmur is correlated with increased disease severity in conditions such as mitral regurgitation or tricuspid regurgitation. However, this patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis, in which murmur intensity has no correlation with disease severity. In patients with very severe mitral stenosis the murmur may even be inaudible due to the severe limitation of blood flow across the stenotic valve.

E) INCORRECT:

Absence of the A2 component of the S2 heart sound can be a sign of worsening aortic stenosis. S2 is comprised of a louder aortic contribution (A2) and a softer pulmonary contribution (P2). As stenosis of the aortic semilunar valves worsens, the A2 diminishes until it is no longer audible. However, this patient's echocardiography is consistent with mitral stenosis, in which there is no change in S2 as the disease increases in severity.
questions.hint: This patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis (MS).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a 5-month history of hoarseness, exertional dyspnea, and fatigue. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His pulse is 98/min and irregular. His voice is coarse in quality. Physical examination shows a liver span of 16 cm and a soft diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hoarseness?

choices.text: Carcinoma arising from the mucosa of the larynx
Extrinsic impingement of the recurrent laryngeal nerve
Bacterial infection of the vocal folds
Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Laryngeal inflammation due to chemical irritant

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A squamous cell carcinoma arising from laryngeal mucosa can cause hoarseness, fatigue, dyspnea due to lung metastases and, rarely, hepatomegaly due to liver metastases. However, a laryngeal malignancy would not explain the atrial fibrillation and the diastolic murmur in this patient without risk factors for laryngeal malignancy such as smoking and alcohol consumption.

B) CORRECT:

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve winds around the arch of the aorta. Massive enlargement of the left atrium (and potentially also the pulmonary artery) in patients with mitral stenosis can compress this nerve resulting in hoarseness (Ortner syndrome). Other rare complications associated with massive left atrial enlargement are massive hemoptysis due to erosion of the bronchial arteries and esophageal compression (dysphagia megalatriensis).
Image Description:

Pleura and pericardium partially resected; removal of the thyroid gland reveals the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection of the vocal folds (laryngitis) with bacteria such as Moraxella catarrhalis, Hemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause hoarseness and fatigue, but the onset of symptoms would be acute, unlike in this patient, who has had symptoms for the past 5 months, and would likely include sore throat or a dry cough. Moreover, laryngitis would not cause exertional dyspnea, fatigue, hepatomegaly, or a diastolic murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with atrial fibrillation are at increased risk for a thromboembolic stroke, and a stroke in the region of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (lateral medullary syndrome) could cause hoarseness due to nucleus ambiguus infarction and dyspnea due to dorsal vagal nucleus infarction as well as fatigue. However, hoarseness and dyspnea would have been acute and preceded the onset of fatigue by weeks to months (post-stroke fatigue). Moreover, a PICA stroke would also cause other clinical features such as dysphagia, vertigo, nystagmus, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral Horner syndrome, and decreased pain and temperature sensation in one side of the face and the contralateral half of the body.
Image Description:

Transverse section

Typically, the efferent cranial nuclei are located medially while the afferent nuclei are located more laterally.

E) INCORRECT:

Laryngeal inflammation from acidic gastric contents, which occurs in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), can cause persistent hoarseness, but it would not cause exertional dyspnea, fatigue, hepatomegaly, or a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, this patient does not have other common features of GERD such as postprandial chest pain, belching, or dry cough.

F) INCORRECT:

Circulating acetylcholine receptor antibodies are seen in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG), which can cause fluctuating fatigue, hoarseness, stridor, and, rarely, dyspnea. The classic presentation of this condition includes diplopia and ptosis that worsen as the day progresses, neither of which have been reported by this patient. In addition, MG would not cause atrial fibrillation, a diastolic murmur, or hepatomegaly.
questions.hint: This patient's fatigue, exertional dyspnea, irregular heart rhythm, and hepatomegaly suggest atrial fibrillation and congestive heart failure (CHF). In this setting, the diastolic murmur at the apex is concerning for mitral stenosis, which commonly leads to left atrial dilation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for increasing shortness of breath with exercise over the past 2 months. She used to walk around her neighborhood every evening, but now has difficulty carrying out her daily activities. She has also started sleeping with three pillows at night. She remembers being hospitalized due to a serious illness during her childhood but has not seen a doctor since emigrating from Bangladesh 7 years ago. Physical examination shows crackles at the bilateral lung bases. There is an opening snap followed by a late diastolic rumble heard best at the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Which of the labeled points in the overview best corresponds to the physiologic opening time of the heart valve that is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Point A corresponds to atrial systole, which occurs in late ventricular diastole when the atria contract to eject blood into the ventricle. Atrial contraction can be associated with an S4 heart sound, which is generated by increased atrial pressure due to contraction against a noncompliant ventricle (e.g., due to ventricular hypertrophy).

B) INCORRECT:

Point B corresponds to the mitral valve closure, marking the beginning of systole. The interval between the closure of the mitral valve and the opening of the aortic valve is the isovolumetric contraction phase, in which left ventricular pressure increases significantly before the aortic valve opens and systolic ejection starts. Impaired closure of the mitral valve during systole (e.g., due to infective endocarditis) causes mitral regurgitation (MR). MR is characterized by a holosystolic murmur, which is best heard at the apex and radiates to the axilla.

C) INCORRECT:

Point C corresponds to the aortic valve opening, which follows isovolumetric contraction and marks the beginning of the systolic ejection phase of the cardiac cycle. Impaired opening of the aortic valve is seen in aortic stenosis, which is often caused by aortic valve calcification in elderly persons. Aortic stenosis is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur and a soft S2 heart sound that is best heard at the right 2nd intercostal space.

D) INCORRECT:

Point D corresponds to the aortic valve closure. The closure of the aortic valve corresponds to the 2nd heart sound and marks the end of systole and the beginning of diastole. The interval between the closure of the aortic valve and the opening of the mitral valve is the isovolumetric relaxation phase, in which the left ventricular pressure drops significantly before the ventricular filling starts during diastole. Impaired closure of the aortic valve (e.g., due to a bicuspid aortic valve) causes aortic regurgitation, which is characterized as a high-pitched early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left 3rd intercostal space (Erb's point).

E) CORRECT:

Point E corresponds to the mitral valve opening. The opening of the mitral valve follows isovolumetric relaxation of the ventricles and marks the beginning of the rapid filling phase of diastole. In mitral stenosis, mitral valve opening is impaired, which is associated with a decreased left ventricular filling and a decreased left ventricular end-diastolic volume (EDV). Decreased EDV results in decreased stroke volume and decreased cardiac output, which causes this patient's features of left heart failure.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
12: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
23: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
34: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
41: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)
questions.hint: This patient's features of left heart failure (e.g., exertional dyspnea, orthopnea) and heart murmur indicate mitral stenosis. Her history of childhood illness suggests rheumatic fever, a known cause of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 27-year-old woman is referred to a cardiologist because of a murmur detected by her general practitioner during a routine health maintenance examination. She has a history of recurrent episodes of sore throat and fever during childhood. She emigrated from Kenya 6 years ago. Cardiac examination shows an opening snap followed by a late diastolic rumble, which is best heard at the fifth intercostal space in the left midclavicular line. Which of the following pressure-volume loop graphs is most likely to correspond to this patient's cardiac condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Graph A indicates aortic stenosis (AS). In AS, the left-ventricular end-systolic volume (top left) is greater than normal because outflow is impeded by the narrowed aortic valve, and the end-diastolic volume (bottom right) is slightly greater than normal due to the increase in residual volume from the previous systole. The stroke volume (the width of the pressure-volume loop) is less than normal because the mild increase in end-diastolic volume does not lead to sufficient preload to overcome the increased opening resistance of the stenotic valve. However, in mild aortic stenosis, the increased preload (increased end-diastolic volume) can result in a more forceful contraction (due to the Frank-Starling mechanism), such that the stroke volume is not decreased. The peak systolic pressure also rises far above normal in order to overcome the high vascular resistance and turbulent blood flow created by the stenosed aortic valve. In contrast to this patient's auscultation findings, AS would classically manifest with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur best heard over the second right intercostal space.

B) INCORRECT:

Graph B indicates mitral regurgitation (MR). The left-ventricular end-diastolic volume (bottom right) is increased because each subsequent diastolic filling includes the normal left atrial volume of blood as well as regurgitated blood from the previous cycle. This ventricular volume overload results in increased preload, which increases the stroke volume (via the Frank-Starling mechanism). This is apparent in the widened pressure-volume loop. There is no true isovolumetric contraction phase in the mitral regurgitation pressure-volume loop, as blood flows back to the left atrium during contraction of the ventricle before the aortic valve opens (top right). The stroke volume is divided between the output through the aortic valve and through the abnormal regurgitant mitral valve, causing a reduced afterload ( outflow resistance) and smaller end-systolic volume (top left). MR would present with a high-pitched holosystolic murmur which is best heard over the apex and radiates to the left axilla, which is not consistent with this patient's auscultation findings.

C) INCORRECT:

Graph C indicates aortic regurgitation (AR). The end-diastolic volume (bottom right) is greater than normal because blood flows into the left ventricle from both the left atrium and from the aorta. This ventricular volume overload results in an increased preload, which increases the stroke volume (via the Frank-Starling mechanism). This is apparent in the widened pressure-volume loop. There is no true isovolumetric relaxation phase because, when the left ventricle begins to relax following aortic valve closure (top left), blood flows backwards from the aorta into the left ventricle. This, in turn, increases left ventricular volume prior to the opening of the mitral valve (bottom left). AR would manifest with an early diastolic high-pitched decrescendo murmur best heard along the left sternal border, which is not consistent with this patient's auscultation findings.

D) CORRECT:

The pressure-volume loop in graph D indicates mitral stenosis. It shows decreased volume at end-diastole (bottom right), a direct result of the narrowed mitral valve opening. According to the Frank-Starling law, a lowered end-diastolic volume leads to reduced left ventricular preload, resulting in decreased stroke volume and cardiac output. This is apparent in the narrowed pressure-volume loop. A decrease in stroke volume, in turn, reduces the afterload imposed on the left ventricle (via reduction of aortic pressure). This can result in a slightly decreased left-ventricular volume at end-systole (top left).
Image Description:

For comparison, a normal pressure-volume diagram is shown on both sides (red).

Left diagram (increased preload): Because of an increase of the end-diastolic volume, the previous starting point is pushed to the right (1 1a). Larger volumes of blood in the ventricles stretch the cardiac muscle fibers, leading to an increase in the force of contraction. This results in a greater stroke volume (yellow bar), which roughly leads to normalization of the end-systolic volume again (4a 4).

Right diagram (increased afterload): When the heart has to eject its stroke volume against a greater aortic pressure from the same starting point (1 = 1a) on the end-diastolic pressure-volume relationship (EDPVR) curve (i.e., same stretching of cardiac muscle fibers), the stroke volume can't be ejected entirely (stroke volume drops: yellow bar < red bar). Subsequently, at the end of the first cycle (yellow), an increased end-systolic volume remains within the heart (4 4a), which leads to an increased end-diastolic volume (1b). The heart reacts to this increased preload by ejecting a greater stroke volume, just as in the left diagram.

E) INCORRECT:

Graph E indicates ventricular systolic dysfunction. The end-systolic volume (top left) is greater than normal due to a decreased contractility of the left ventricle. A compensatory increase in end-diastolic volume (bottom right) elevates preload and functions to help maintain stroke volume via the Frank-Starling mechanism. Although this elevates the stroke volume so that it is almost normal, ejection fraction is still significantly reduced. Patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction typically present with dyspnea, fatigue and edemas, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, unlike this patient's auscultatory findings, heart failure would manifest with an S3/S4 gallop.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur is characteristic of mitral stenosis. Her history of recurrent fever and sore throat before emigrating from Kenya indicates that she may have had rheumatic fever, a known cause of mitral stenosis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and nocturnal cough for the past 2 weeks. On two occasions, his cough was bloody. He had a heart condition as a child that was treated with antibiotics. He emigrated to the US from Kazakhstan 15 years ago. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although aortic regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), it causes a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best parasternally at the second intercostal space, and may sometimes be accompanied by an Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in developed countries and is often caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is usually asymptomatic and is best heard at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line as a mid-systolic high-frequency click.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis is usually congenital and causes a systolic murmur best heard at the second left intercostal space parasternally. It can radiate to the back and also be present as a widely split second heart sound, but this is not consistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's diastolic murmur at the fifth intercostal space and opening snap indicate mitral stenosis, which causes an increase in left atrial pressure (and PCWP) and a backup of blood into the lungs. The volume overload eventually causes symptoms of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which explain this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. This patient most likely had rheumatic fever as a child, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles). However, it presents as a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex of the fifth left intercostal space, in contrast to this patient's diastolic murmur.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as pansystolic murmur in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

Although severe aortic valve stenosis may eventually cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), patients would most likely first present with syncope or angina. Furthermore, aortic stenosis causes a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space, which can radiate to the carotids.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve stenosis is extremely rare and can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it causes a diastolic murmur best heard at the left fourth intercostal space parasternally and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo
questions.hint: This patient's heart problem is consistent with a history of rheumatic fever. An x-ray of the chest in this patient could show left atrial enlargement as a result of this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman develops dyspnea, orthopnea, and hypoxia 2 days after an uncomplicated semiurgent cholecystectomy. Her only postoperative management has been intravenous fluids and analgesics.
She has a regular heart rate of 120 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 112/76 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 88% while breathing ambient air. She has bilateral inspiratory rales to her mid-lung fields, a nondisplaced point of maximal impulse, a right parasternal heave, and a 3/6 holodiastolic rumbling murmur at the apex, with presystolic accentuation.
In addition to discontinuing intravenous fluids, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulants, such as unfractionated heparin, would be used to treat pulmonary embolism. Patients with acute pulmonary embolism may have evidence of right heart strain on physical examination, including a soft systolic murmur suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation due to high pulmonary pressures or an accentuated P2 heart sound, but they would not be expected to have a holodiastolic murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitroprusside is effective in treating pulmonary edema in patients with markedly elevated blood pressure or left ventricular systolic dysfunction or in patients with some regurgitant valve lesions, but it is not indicated in patients with mitral stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics would be the treatment for sepsis that is commonly associated with systolic ejection murmurs in the absence of structural heart disease. It is highly unlikely in this case because it would not account for the cardiac findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Dobutamine is an inotropic and chronotropic agent used to treat heart failure; in this case, it would result in tachycardia and likely worsen the magnitude of pulmonary congestion.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests pulmonary edema secondary to mitral stenosis. Mitral stenosis causes impaired filling of the left ventricle, with elevated pressures in the left atrium, pulmonary vessels, and right heart chambers. Pulmonary edema can be triggered by tachycardia, excessive fluid administration, or both. Initial treatment of a patient with mitral stenosis, pulmonary edema, and tachycardia should focus on diuresis (usually with loop diuretics). Once the pulmonary edema has improved, then addition of a beta-blocker for further optimization of myocardial activity should be considered.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medication for a patient with pulmonary edema and tachycardia secondary to mitral stenosis is a diuretic.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man who is originally from India presents with progressive shortness of breath and palpitations. He has no known medical history.
Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular heart rate of 120 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 93% while the patient is receiving 3 liters of supplemental oxygen. The patient is in mild respiratory distress and has bibasilar crackles in his lungs. Cardiac examination reveals a high-pitched sound after the second heart sound, followed by a faint diastolic rumble heard best at the apex.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals bilateral infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema. A rhythm strip is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely explanation for this patients clinical presentation?

choices.text: Thickening and fusion of the mitral valve leaflets
Calcific degeneration of the aortic valve
Myxomatous degeneration of the leaflets of the mitral valve
Incomplete fusion of the atrial septum primum and secundum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

New-onset atrial fibrillation, pulmonary edema, an opening snap, and a diastolic rumble are typical manifestations of mitral stenosis. Rheumatic valvular disease is especially common in developing countries, such as India. The infection results in thickening and nodularity of the mitral valve leaflets and fusion of the commissures.

Key learning point: Atrial fibrillation and a diastolic rumbling murmur at the cardiac apex are characteristic of rheumatic mitral stenosis, with thickening and fusion of the mitral leaflets.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcific degeneration of the aortic valve, a common cause of aortic stenosis in older adults, is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

A congenital bicuspid aortic valve can cause aortic stenosis, regurgitation, or both. Neither of these diagnoses is associated with an opening snap or apical diastolic murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve leaflets is characteristic of mitral valve prolapse, which often results in mitral regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Incomplete fusion of the atrial septum primum and secundum causes a patent foramen ovale, which does not cause a murmur.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who is originally from India presents with progressive shortness of breath and palpitations. He has no known medical history. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and an oxygen saturation of 93% while the patient is receiving 3 liters of supplemental oxygen. The patient is in mild respiratory distress and has bibasilar crackles in his lungs. Cardiac examination reveals a high-pitched sound after the second heart sound, followed by a faint diastolic rumble heard best at the apex. A chest radiograph shows bilateral infiltrates consistent with pulmonary edema. A rhythm strip shows an irregularly irregular rhythm, no discernable P waves, and narrow QRS complexes. What is the most likely explanation for this patients clinical presentation?

choices.text: Thickening and fusion of the mitral valve leaflets
Calcific degeneration of the aortic valve
Myxomatous degeneration of the leaflets of the mitral valve
Incomplete fusion of the atrial septum primum and secundum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

New-onset atrial fibrillation, pulmonary edema, an opening snap, and a diastolic rumble are typical manifestations of mitral stenosis. Rheumatic valvular disease is especially common in developing countries, such as India. The infection results in thickening and nodularity of the mitral valve leaflets and fusion of the commissures.

Key learning point: Atrial fibrillation and a diastolic rumbling murmur at the cardiac apex are characteristic of rheumatic mitral stenosis, with thickening and fusion of the mitral leaflets.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcific degeneration of the aortic valve, a common cause of aortic stenosis in older adults, is characterized by a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

A congenital bicuspid aortic valve can cause aortic stenosis, regurgitation, or both. Neither of these diagnoses is associated with an opening snap or apical diastolic murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve leaflets is characteristic of mitral valve prolapse, which often results in mitral regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Incomplete fusion of the atrial septum primum and secundum causes a patent foramen ovale, which does not cause a murmur.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of shortness of breath with exertion. He immigrated to the United States from Ghana 20 years ago. His pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Echocardiography shows thickened mitral valve leaflets with reduced motion and a narrowed mitral valve orifice diameter. Which of the following auscultation findings is most likely to correlate with the severity of this patient's valvular disease?

choices.text: Decreased time between S2 and opening snap
Radiation of murmur to the axilla

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased time between the aortic component of S2 and the opening snap (OS) occurs due to increasing left atrial pressure (LAP) brought on by worsening MS. The greater the LAP, the faster the acceleration of valve leaflets to the maximal point of opening, and the sooner the opening snap occurs after S2. The most common cause of MS in developing countries is rheumatic fever.

Atrial fibrillation and pulmonary hypertension are also associated with poor prognosis in patients with MS.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

B) INCORRECT:

The presence of a mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur is associated with mitral valve prolapse. The click occurs as the chordae tendinae anchoring the prolapsed valve leaflet reach their maximum length and snap tight. However, this patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis, which does not manifest with a mid-systolic click.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation of a murmur to the axilla is most noticeable in mitral regurgitation. However, this patient's echocardiography is consistent with mitral stenosis, which is best heard from the apex and is not known to radiate.

D) INCORRECT:

An increased intensity of a murmur is correlated with increased disease severity in conditions such as mitral regurgitation or tricuspid regurgitation. However, this patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis, in which murmur intensity has no correlation with disease severity. In patients with very severe mitral stenosis the murmur may even be inaudible due to the severe limitation of blood flow across the stenotic valve.

E) INCORRECT:

Absence of the A2 component of the S2 heart sound can be a sign of worsening aortic stenosis. S2 is comprised of a louder aortic contribution (A2) and a softer pulmonary contribution (P2). As stenosis of the aortic semilunar valves worsens, the A2 diminishes until it is no longer audible. However, this patient's echocardiography is consistent with mitral stenosis, in which there is no change in S2 as the disease increases in severity.
questions.hint: This patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis (MS).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman develops dyspnea, orthopnea, and hypoxia 2 days after an uncomplicated semiurgent cholecystectomy. Her only postoperative management has been intravenous fluids and analgesics. She has a regular heart rate of 120 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 112/76 mm Hg, and an oxygen saturation of 88% while breathing ambient air. She has bilateral inspiratory rales to her mid-lung fields, a nondisplaced point of maximal impulse, a right parasternal heave, and a 3/6 holodiastolic rumbling murmur at the apex, with presystolic accentuation. In addition to discontinuing intravenous fluids, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulants, such as unfractionated heparin, would be used to treat pulmonary embolism. Patients with acute pulmonary embolism may have evidence of right heart strain on physical examination, including a soft systolic murmur suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation due to high pulmonary pressures or an accentuated P 2 heart sound, but they would not be expected to have a holodiastolic murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitroprusside is effective in treating pulmonary edema in patients with markedly elevated blood pressure or left ventricular systolic dysfunction or in patients with some regurgitant valve lesions, but it is not indicated in patients with mitral stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics would be the treatment for sepsis that is commonly associated with systolic ejection murmurs in the absence of structural heart disease. It is highly unlikely in this case because it would not account for the cardiac findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Dobutamine is an inotropic and chronotropic agent used to treat heart failure; in this case, it would result in tachycardia and likely worsen the magnitude of pulmonary congestion.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests pulmonary edema secondary to mitral stenosis. Mitral stenosis causes impaired filling of the left ventricle, with elevated pressures in the left atrium, pulmonary vessels, and right heart chambers. Pulmonary edema can be triggered by tachycardia, excessive fluid administration, or both. Initial treatment of a patient with mitral stenosis, pulmonary edema, and tachycardia should focus on diuresis (usually with loop diuretics). Once the pulmonary edema has improved, then addition of a beta-blocker for further optimization of myocardial activity should be considered.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medication for a patient with pulmonary edema and tachycardia secondary to mitral stenosis is a diuretic.
questions.hint: A 3/6 holodiastolic rumbling murmur at the apex with presystolic accentuation is characteristic of mitral stenosis .

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of increasing shortness of breath for 1 month. Initially, he was able to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment, but he now needs several breaks to catch his breath. He has rheumatic heart disease. Examination shows bilateral crackles at the lung bases. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Echocardiography shows no valvular calcifications, atrial clots, or atrioventricular regurgitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve repair is indicated for symptomatic or severe aortic valve disease. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease. Both aortic regurgitation (AR) and aortic stenosis (AS) can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, unlike this patient's murmur, AR causes a blowing early diastolic murmur heard best at the left midsternal border and AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of aortic regurgitation

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged. The left ventricle, ascending aorta, and aortic arch are prominent as a result of dilatation.

B) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) are indicated for patients with heart failure because they have been shown to reduce mortality (likely via aldosterone reduction, which decreases myocardial remodeling, among other mechanisms). Although this patient has symptoms of heart failure, ACE inhibitors (and other afterload reduction agents) are contraindicated in mitral valve stenosis, which decreases the preload available for the left ventricle to pump into the systemic circulation, meaning that the ability to maintain perfusion of vital organs is already compromised. If the ability of peripheral arteries to constrict is downregulated (e.g., by an ACE inhibitor), then perfusion may be insufficient and end-organ damage may occur.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is the treatment of choice for most cases of symptomatic or severe aortic stenosis (AS) in patients who are not suited to surgery. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease, with AS being less common than aortic regurgitation. AS can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Warfarin therapy would be indicated if this patient had evidence of atrial fibrillation (e.g., irregular heart rhythm), evidence of left atrial thrombus (e.g., echocardiographic finding or embolic stroke), or a mechanical heart valve. Although this patient is at risk for all of these conditions given his mitral valve stenosis and may require warfarin in the future, there is no clear indication for warfarin at this time.

E) CORRECT:

Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC) is the treatment of choice for many cases of symptomatic mitral stenosis because it improves valve function and symptoms, is less invasive, and the morbidity and mortality rates are lower than with other surgical treatment options. This patient has a favorable valve morphology (no calcifications) and no evidence of a left atrial thrombus or mitral regurgitation, which makes him a good candidate for PMBC. If the patient's echocardiography were less benign, open valvular replacement would be indicated.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.
questions.hint: A low-pitched diastolic murmur with an opening snap in a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease is characteristic of mitral valve stenosis. These findings in combination with exertional dyspnea and bibasilar crackles without chest pain indicate cardiogenic pulmonary edema and heart failure due to valvular disease.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old G2P1 woman with known rheumatic mitral stenosis presents at 28 weeks gestation with three weeks of worsening dyspnea, orthopnea, and mild fatigue. Auscultation reveals an accentuated first heart sound and a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. Bilateral basal crackles are present.


Heart rate
90/min


Blood pressure
110/68 mm Hg


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous balloon valvuloplasty is reserved for severe symptomatic mitral stenosis unresponsive to medical management or with hemodynamic instability. This patient, with stable vital signs and mild symptoms, is more appropriately managed initially with medical therapy, such as diuretics, to relieve pulmonary congestion. The procedure involves fetal radiation exposure, so it is not the first-line intervention.

B) CORRECT:

In pregnancy, increased blood volume and cardiac output can exacerbate mitral stenosis, leading to elevated left atrial pressures and pulmonary congestion. This patient presents with dyspnea, orthopnea, and basal crackles, indicating pulmonary venous congestion. Low-dose loop diuretics reduce circulating volume and preload, alleviating pulmonary congestion. They are safe in pregnancy and recommended for symptomatic heart failure management in this context.

Key learning point: In pregnancy, the increase in stroke volume and cardiac output can exacerbate pre-existing cardiac conditions like mitral stenosis, increasing the risk of heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers are used in mitral stenosis to control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation. This patient has a stable heart rate of 90/min and no arrhythmia. The primary issue is pulmonary congestion due to elevated left atrial pressure, not excessive heart rate. Beta-blockers could reduce myocardial contractility, worsening hemodynamics in this context.

D) INCORRECT:

Urgent cesarean delivery is considered in severe maternal instability. This patient, at 28 weeks gestation, has stable vital signs and mild symptoms, indicating a heart failure exacerbation manageable with medical therapy. Immediate delivery would expose the preterm neonate to risks without addressing the mother's cardiac condition.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a one-month history of shortness of breath when lying on her back. She has also experienced several episodes of coughing up blood during this time. She reports a history of a heart problem in childhood that was treated with antibiotics. She emigrated from Russia 5 years ago. There is no family history of serious illness. On pulmonary examination, you hear crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is provided. An ECG shows tachycardia and absence of P waves. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles). However, it manifests as a holosystolic murmur (i.e., audible between S1 and S2) best heard at the apex of the fifth left intercostal space, in contrast to this patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2).

B) INCORRECT:

Although severe aortic valve stenosis may eventually cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), patients would most likely first present with syncope or angina. Furthermore, aortic stenosis causes a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space, which can radiate to the carotids.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in developed countries and is often caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is usually asymptomatic and is best heard at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line as a high-frequency mid-to-late systolic murmur with a mid-systolic click.

D) INCORRECT:

Although aortic regurgitation may lead to signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), it causes a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best parasternally at the second intercostal space, and may sometimes be accompanied by an Austin Flint murmur.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2) at the fifth left intercostal space and opening snap indicate mitral valve stenosis, which causes an increase in left atrial pressure (and increased pulmonary wedge pressure) and a backup of blood into the lungs. Volume overload eventually causes symptoms of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which explains this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. The absence of P waves confirms atrial fibrillation, a common complication of mitral stenosis. This patient most likely suffered from rheumatic fever, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.

Key learning point: Mitral valve stenosis, often due to rheumatic fever, presents with a diastolic murmur, atrial fibrillation, and symptoms of pulmonary congestion such as orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.
questions.hint: This patient's heart problem is consistent with a history of rheumatic fever. An x-ray of the chest in this patient would likely show left atrial enlargement as a result of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to your clinic with worsening fatigue and shortness of breath. Her symptoms started 8 months ago and have progressively worsened. She reports a history of recurrent joint pain and fever during childhood. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She emigrated from the Congo with her parents at age 12. Her temperature is 37.4째C, pulse is 90/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. On examination, there is an opening snap followed by a diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space in the midclavicular line. If left untreated, which one of the following complications is she at greatest risk for?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retinal vein occlusion is a complication of systemic disease such as atherosclerosis, diabetes mellitus, and vasculitis, and is also seen in patients with hypercoagulable states (e.g., polycythemia vera, sickle cell disease, oral contraceptive use). Patients with mitral stenosis and concurrent atrial fibrillation due to an enlarged left atrium are at increased risk of retinal artery occlusion secondary to embolization from the atria.

B) INCORRECT:

Ventricular tachycardia is a serious type of arrhythmia that arises from the ventricle. Patients with mitral stenosis due to rheumatic heart disease are more likely to develop supraventricular tachyarrhythmia such as atrial fibrillation due to atrial enlargement.

C) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) is associated most commonly with chronic hypertension and aortic stenosis. Patients with untreated, severe mitral stenosis are instead at increased risk of developing right ventricular hypertrophy due to pulmonary artery hypertension (from high left atrial pressures). The presence of an opening snap in this patient is suggestive of mitral stenosis, of which LVH is not a common complication.

D) INCORRECT:

Nephritic syndrome due to poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune-complex mediated complication of streptococcal infection. This patient, who has rheumatic heart disease, has most certainly had a streptococcal infection during childhood or early adolescence. However, PSGN occurs within 16 weeks of streptococcal infection in the same age group; it would not occur in adulthood.

E) CORRECT:

Long-standing mitral stenosis can lead to an enlarged left atrium due to chronically elevated left atrial pressures. In some patients, the atrium may become so massively enlarged that it can compress the esophagus. In only very rare cases do patients develop esophageal compression that is severe enough to cause dysphagia (dysphagia megalatriensis).

Other rare complications associated with massive enlargement of the left atrium include recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy (Ortner syndrome) and massive hemoptysis due to erosion of the bronchial arteries.

Key learning point: Progressive mitral stenosis can cause left atrial enlargement, which may lead to complications such as esophageal compression and atrial fibrillation.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A convexity between the moguls produced by the main pulmonary artery (PA) and left ventricle (LV) suggests enlargement of the left atrial appendage (LAA; normal configuration indicated by dashed line). Breast shadow opacification (green overlay) simulates parenchymal airspace disease.

AA: aortic arch
questions.hint: The patient's clinical features indicate progressive mitral stenosis. The most common cause of mitral stenosis in a young adult is rheumatic heart disease (RHD), which usually develops 1030 years after one or more episodes of rheumatic fever. Rheumatic fever occurs during childhood following streptococcal pharyngitis and is characterized by fever and joint pain. A history of immigration from a developing country is an important risk factor for RHD.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of exertional shortness of breath. He immigrated from Ghana 20 years ago. His pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Echocardiography reveals thickened mitral valve leaflets with reduced motion and a narrowed mitral valve orifice diameter. Which one of the following auscultation findings is most likely to correlate with the severity of his valvular disease?

choices.text: Radiation of murmur to the axilla.
Decreased time between S2 and opening snap.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of a mid-systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur is associated with mitral valve prolapse. The click occurs as the chordae tendinae anchoring the prolapsed valve leaflet reach their maximum length and snap tight. However, this patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis, which does not manifest with a mid-systolic click.

B) INCORRECT:

Absence of the A2 component of the S2 heart sound can be a sign of worsening aortic stenosis. S2 is comprised of a louder aortic contribution (A2) and a softer pulmonary contribution (P2). As stenosis of the aortic semilunar valves worsens, the A2 diminishes until it is no longer audible.
