However, this patient's echocardiography is consistent with mitral stenosis, in which there is no change in S2 as the disease increases in severity.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation of a murmur to the axilla is most noticeable in mitral regurgitation. However, this patient's echocardiography is consistent with mitral stenosis, which is best heard from the apex and is not known to radiate.

D) INCORRECT:

An increased intensity of a murmur is correlated with increased disease severity in conditions such as mitral regurgitation or tricuspid regurgitation. However, this patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis, in which murmur intensity has no correlation with disease severity. In patients with very severe mitral stenosis the murmur may even be inaudible due to the severe limitation of blood flow across the stenotic valve.

E) CORRECT:

Decreased time between the aortic component of S2 and the opening snap (OS) occurs due to increasing left atrial pressure (LAP) brought on by worsening MS. The greater the LAP, the faster the acceleration of valve leaflets to the maximal point of opening, and the sooner the opening snap occurs after S2. The most common cause of MS in developing countries is rheumatic fever.

Atrial fibrillation and pulmonary hypertension are also associated with poor prognosis in patients with MS.

Key learning point: In mitral stenosis, a shorter interval between S2 and the opening snap indicates higher left atrial pressure and greater disease severity.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.
questions.hint: This patient's echocardiography findings are consistent with mitral stenosis (MS).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of increasing shortness of breath. He reports that he was previously able to climb three flights of stairs to his apartment without difficulty, but now needs to take several breaks to catch his breath. He has a history of rheumatic heart disease. On examination, there are bilateral crackles at the lung bases. Cardiac examination reveals an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Echocardiography shows no valvular calcifications, atrial clots, or atrioventricular regurgitation. Which one of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC) is the treatment of choice for many cases of symptomatic mitral stenosis because it improves valve function and symptoms, is less invasive, and the morbidity and mortality rates are lower than with other surgical treatment options. This patient has a favorable valve morphology (no calcifications) and no evidence of a left atrial thrombus or mitral regurgitation, which makes him a good candidate for PMBC. If the patient's echocardiography were less benign, open valvular replacement would be indicated.

Key learning point: Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy is the preferred treatment for symptomatic mitral stenosis without valve calcification, left atrial thrombus, or significant regurgitation.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

B) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) are indicated for patients with heart failure because they have been shown to reduce mortality (likely via aldosterone reduction, which decreases myocardial remodeling, among other mechanisms). Although this patient has symptoms of heart failure, ACE inhibitors (and other afterload reduction agents) are contraindicated in mitral valve stenosis, which decreases the preload available for the left ventricle to pump into the systemic circulation, meaning that the ability to maintain perfusion of vital organs is already compromised. If the ability of peripheral arteries to constrict is downregulated (e.g., by an ACE inhibitor), then perfusion may be insufficient and end-organ damage may occur.

C) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is the treatment of choice for most cases of symptomatic or severe aortic stenosis (AS) in patients who are not suited to surgery. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease, with AS being less common than aortic regurgitation. AS can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Warfarin therapy would be indicated if this patient had evidence of atrial fibrillation (e.g., irregular heart rhythm), evidence of left atrial thrombus (e.g., echocardiographic finding or embolic stroke), or a mechanical heart valve. Although this patient is at risk for all of these conditions given his mitral valve stenosis and may require warfarin in the future, there is no clear indication for warfarin at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve repair is indicated for symptomatic or severe aortic valve disease. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease. Both aortic regurgitation (AR) and aortic stenosis (AS) can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, unlike this patient's murmur, AR causes a blowing early diastolic murmur heard best at the left midsternal border and AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space.
questions.hint: A low-pitched diastolic murmur with an opening snap in a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease is characteristic of mitral valve stenosis. These findings in combination with exertional dyspnea and bibasilar crackles without chest pain indicate cardiogenic pulmonary edema and heart failure due to valvular disease.

questions.text: You are caring for a 46-year-old woman who develops dyspnea, orthopnea, and hypoxia 2 days after an uncomplicated semiurgent cholecystectomy. Her postoperative management has included intravenous fluids and analgesics. Her heart rate is 120 beats per minute, blood pressure is 112/76 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On examination, she has bilateral inspiratory rales to the mid-lung fields, a nondisplaced point of maximal impulse, a right parasternal heave, and a 3/6 holodiastolic rumbling murmur at the apex with presystolic accentuation. In addition to discontinuing intravenous fluids, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dobutamine is an inotropic and chronotropic agent used to treat heart failure; in this case, it would result in tachycardia and likely worsen the magnitude of pulmonary congestion.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulants, such as unfractionated heparin, would be used to treat pulmonary embolism. Patients with acute pulmonary embolism may have evidence of right heart strain on physical examination, including a soft systolic murmur suggestive of tricuspid regurgitation due to high pulmonary pressures or an accentuated P 2 heart sound, but they would not be expected to have a holodiastolic murmur.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation suggests pulmonary edema secondary to mitral stenosis. Mitral stenosis causes impaired filling of the left ventricle, with elevated pressures in the left atrium, pulmonary vessels, and right heart chambers. Pulmonary edema can be triggered by tachycardia, excessive fluid administration, or both. Initial treatment of a patient with mitral stenosis, pulmonary edema, and tachycardia should focus on diuresis (usually with loop diuretics). Once the pulmonary edema has improved, then addition of a beta-blocker for further optimization of myocardial activity should be considered.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medication for a patient with pulmonary edema and tachycardia secondary to mitral stenosis is a diuretic.

D) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics would be the treatment for sepsis that is commonly associated with systolic ejection murmurs in the absence of structural heart disease. It is highly unlikely in this case because it would not account for the cardiac findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitroprusside is effective in treating pulmonary edema in patients with markedly elevated blood pressure or left ventricular systolic dysfunction or in patients with some regurgitant valve lesions, but it is not indicated in patients with mitral stenosis.
questions.hint: A 3/6 holodiastolic rumbling murmur at the apex with presystolic accentuation is characteristic of mitral stenosis .

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of rheumatic fever presents with a 6-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and fatigue. She reports increasing difficulty climbing stairs and mild swelling in her legs. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 88; R, 18; oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm. Cardiac auscultation reveals a loud first heart sound, an opening snap after S2, and a low-pitched diastolic murmur best heard at the cardiac apex when the patient is positioned on her left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While the history of rheumatic fever, exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and irregular rhythm could suggest mitral regurgitation, the diastolic murmur, opening snap, and loud first heart sound are inconsistent with this diagnosis, which typically produces a holosystolic murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

While exertional dyspnea and fatigue could suggest aortic stenosis, the diastolic murmur at the apex, opening snap, and loud first heart sound are inconsistent with this diagnosis, which produces a systolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border.

C) CORRECT:

Correct The history of rheumatic fever, progressive exertional dyspnea, loud first heart sound, opening snap, and low-pitched diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex are all classic findings of mitral stenosis. The irregularly irregular rhythm suggests atrial fibrillation, which commonly develops secondary to left atrial enlargement from mitral stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

While leg swelling and irregular rhythm could suggest tricuspid regurgitation, the diastolic murmur at the apex, opening snap, and loud first heart sound are inconsistent with this diagnosis, which causes a systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration.

E) INCORRECT:

While the diastolic murmur could suggest aortic regurgitation, the low-pitched quality, apical location, opening snap, and loud first heart sound are inconsistent with this diagnosis, which produces a high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur at the left sternal border.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of rheumatic fever presents with progressive dyspnea over the past week, worsening over the last 6 hours. She reports new palpitations and has not been taking her prescribed medications. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 142; R, 24; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, bilateral pulmonary rales, and peripheral edema. Chest x-ray shows mild pulmonary edema. ECG shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Echocardiography shows a mitral valve area of 1.4 cm짼 with severe left atrial enlargement and left ventricular ejection fraction of 52%. Oxygen therapy is started. What is the next most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The echocardiography demonstrates severe mitral stenosis with severe left atrial enlargement. Pharmacological cardioversion with intravenous amiodarone is not the first-line treatment for new-onset atrial fibrillation in mitral stenosis. Rate control is preferred in mitral stenosis because structural left atrial changes reduce cardioversion success rates, and the valve pathology makes rhythm maintenance difficult. Cardioversion would be indicated if this patient became hemodynamically unstable. Additionally, patients with mitral stenosis have a high thromboembolism risk requiring extensive anticoagulation workup before attempting rhythm control.

B) CORRECT:

Correct The echocardiography shows severe mitral stenosis (valve area 1.4 cm짼) with preserved left ventricular function (LVEF 52%). In patients with mitral stenosis who develop atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, rate control is the immediate priority. The rapid heart rate reduces diastolic filling time across the stenotic valve, decreasing cardiac output and worsening hemodynamic status. This also increases left atrial pressure, which backs up into the pulmonary circulation, causing pulmonary venous congestion and pulmonary edema. Rate control with diltiazem improves ventricular filling, reduces left atrial pressure, and decreases pulmonary congestion. Nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are first-line agents for acute rate control in stable patients without decompensated heart failure. Cardioversion is not preferred here because patients with mitral stenosis have a high thromboembolism risk requiring extensive anticoagulation workup before attempting rhythm control, and the severe left atrial enlargement reduces cardioversion success rates.

C) INCORRECT:

While diuretics may help with pulmonary congestion symptoms, the primary hemodynamic problem in this patient with severe mitral stenosis is the rapid ventricular response reducing diastolic filling time across the stenotic mitral valve. Giving diuretics without first controlling the heart rate could worsen hemodynamic status by reducing preload when the patient already has compromised ventricular filling due to the stenotic valve and shortened diastolic filling time. Rate control must be achieved first to improve cardiac output before addressing volume management.

D) INCORRECT:

The severe left atrial enlargement seen on echocardiography places this patient at high risk for thromboembolism, and anticoagulation with warfarin is indicated for patients with mitral stenosis who develop atrial fibrillation for thromboembolic prevention. However, anticoagulation does not address the immediate hemodynamic compromise from rapid ventricular response that is causing symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

The echocardiographic findings of severe mitral stenosis with new-onset atrial fibrillation are an indication for eventual intervention, such as percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy or surgery. However, this patient requires immediate medical stabilization before any procedural consultation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with known rheumatic heart disease is brought to the emergency department by family members who report she has been increasingly short of breath over the past week, with worsening today. She appears anxious and is sitting upright, unable to lie flat. Vital signs are BP, 108/68 mm Hg; P, 110; R, 28; T, 37.2째C (99.0째F). Oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, bibasilar crackles, and 2+ pitting edema to the knees. ECG shows sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm. Bedside echocardiogram shows a mitral valve area of 0.8 cm짼, a severely enlarged left atrium, and an estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 65 mmHg. What is the most appropriate initial medication?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The echocardiogram shows severe mitral stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm짼, indicating severe mechanical obstruction with fixed cardiac output. Nitroglycerin should be used with caution in mitral stenosis, as vasodilators can precipitate hypotension in patients who cannot compensate for reduced preload and afterload due to fixed cardiac output from the stenotic valve.

B) INCORRECT:

The severe mitral stenosis evidenced by the 0.8 cm짼 valve area and elevated pulmonary pressures of 65 mmHg indicates volume overload. While beta-blockers like metoprolol can be important for rate control in mitral stenosis patients, they are typically considered in patients with atrial fibrillation, or younger patients in sinus rhythm with high resting or exercise-induced heart rates. This 58-year-old patient has sinus tachycardia that is likely compensatory due to acute heart failure rather than a baseline elevated heart rate requiring chronic rate control.

C) INCORRECT:

The echocardiogram shows severe mitral stenosis with mechanical obstruction at the valve level, evidenced by a valve area of 0.8 cm짼. Dobutamine increases cardiac contractility and heart rate, but increasing contractility does not overcome this fixed obstruction, and increasing heart rate reduces diastolic filling time across the stenotic valve.

D) INCORRECT:

The echocardiogram demonstrates severe mitral stenosis with elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 65 mmHg and severely enlarged left atrium, indicating elevated left atrial and pulmonary pressures. Morphine can reduce preload and provide symptomatic relief for dyspnea, but it does not address the underlying volume overload.

E) CORRECT:

Correct The echocardiogram shows severe mitral stenosis with a valve area of 0.8 cm짼 and pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 65 mmHg, indicating acute heart failure from severe mitral stenosis. Heart failure symptoms in mitral stenosis are managed using standard diuretic therapy, and furosemide addresses the pulmonary congestion and peripheral edema. Following acute stabilization, urgent cardiology consultation is required as this patient meets criteria for interventional management given symptomatic severe mitral stenosis. Vasodilators should be used with caution, as patients with fixed cardiac output from mitral stenosis cannot compensate adequately for drops in afterload.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and fatigue. She has a history of a significant febrile illness with joint pains in childhood. On examination, a low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur is heard at the apex, along with a high-pitched sound that occurs shortly after S2. An echocardiogram confirms severe valvular disease and reveals a markedly elevated left atrial pressure. This manometric finding is most closely associated with which of the following auscultatory events?

choices.text: A shorter interval between S2 and the opening snap
A widely fixed splitting of the second heart sound
A longer interval between S2 and the opening snap
Radiation of the diastolic murmur to the axilla
A diminished intensity of the first heart sound

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The auscultatory findings of a diastolic rumble and an opening snap (OS) are classic clinical findings of mitral stenosis. The OS occurs when left ventricular pressure falls below the left atrial pressure (LAP), causing the stenotic mitral valve to open. In severe mitral stenosis, the LAP is markedly elevated. Consequently, the declining left ventricular pressure drops below this high atrial pressure earlier in diastole. This results in an earlier opening of the mitral valve and a shorter interval between S2 and the OS, which is a key clinical indicator of disease severity.

B) INCORRECT:

Widely fixed splitting of S2 is the pathognomonic auscultatory finding for an atrial septal defect (ASD). While ASD can cause exertional dyspnea, it is not associated with a diastolic rumble at the apex or an opening snap. This finding is unrelated to the pathophysiology of mitral stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A longer interval between the second heart sound (S2) and the opening snap (OS) is associated with milder forms of mitral stenosis. In mild disease, the left atrial pressure is not as high, so it takes longer for the isovolumetrically relaxing left ventricle's pressure to fall below the atrial pressure. This is inconsistent with the finding of markedly elevated left atrial pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiation of a murmur to the axilla is a characteristic feature of the holosystolic murmur of mitral regurgitation, not the diastolic murmur of mitral stenosis. The murmur in mitral stenosis is a low-pitched rumble localized to the apex and does not typically radiate to the axilla.

E) INCORRECT:

A diminished intensity of the first heart sound might occur because valvular disease can alter heart sounds. However, classic mitral stenosis is associated with a loud, sharp first heart sound (S1) due to the forceful slamming shut of the mitral leaflets from a wide-open position. A diminished S1 in this context suggests a heavily calcified and immobile valve, which may occur in very advanced disease, but is not the most direct auscultatory correlate of high left atrial pressure.
questions.hint: This patient's history of childhood febrile illness and joint pains is suggestive of rheumatic fever, the leading cause of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a one-year history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. She recalls having recurrent sore throats and joint pains as a child. Her pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular, blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, and respirations are 22/min. Cardiac auscultation reveals a loud first heart sound and a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the apex. An echocardiogram demonstrates a pliable, non-calcified mitral valve with a valve area of 0.9 cm2 and a pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 55 mmHg. There is no significant mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Rate control with a beta-blocker and diuresis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical mitral valve replacement is a definitive treatment for mitral stenosis, but it is typically reserved for patients who are not candidates for a different therapeutic approach. Indications for surgery over other approaches include unfavorable valve anatomy (e.g., significant calcification, rigidity), moderate to severe concomitant mitral regurgitation, or the presence of a left atrial thrombus.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and symptoms of pulmonary congestion, making rate control and diuresis important components of her medical management. However, these therapies only address the symptoms and complications of mitral stenosis. They do not treat the underlying mechanical obstruction at the mitral valve, which is the cause of her severe symptoms and pulmonary hypertension. Therefore, this is not the definitive treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Direct current cardioversion is a treatment for atrial fibrillation aimed at restoring sinus rhythm. While potentially useful, it is unlikely to be successful or sustained in the long term without first correcting the underlying severe mitral stenosis. The stenotic valve causes significant left atrial pressure overload and enlargement, which is a powerful driver for maintaining atrial fibrillation. The primary problem, the valve obstruction, must be addressed first.

D) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation with warfarin is indicated for this patient due to the presence of atrial fibrillation, which significantly increases the risk of thromboembolic events like stroke in the setting of mitral stenosis. While this is a crucial part of her overall management to prevent complications, it does not address the hemodynamic consequences of the stenotic valve. It is a necessary supportive therapy, not the definitive treatment for the valve obstruction itself.

E) CORRECT:

Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC) is the preferred treatment in patients with favorable valve anatomy. The echocardiogram shows a pliable, non-calcified valve without significant mitral regurgitation, which makes her an ideal candidate for this procedure. PMBC involves advancing a balloon catheter across the mitral valve and inflating it to split the fused commissures, thereby increasing the valve area and relieving the obstruction. This patient's history of recurrent sore throats as a child is highly suggestive of rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.
questions.hint: This patient has severe, symptomatic mitral stenosis secondary to rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with a year of gradually worsening exercise intolerance, waking at night with difficulty breathing, and occasional palpitations. She reports an extended hospital stay in childhood for a severe febrile illness. Examination reveals a notably loud first heart sound and a low-pitched, rumbling murmur audible at the apex with the bell of the stethoscope.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation is characterized by a high-pitched, blowing holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex and radiating toward the axilla. The murmur described is low-pitched and rumbling, with an accentuated first heart sound, indicating restricted valve opening rather than regurgitation. These features do not align with mitral regurgitation.

B) CORRECT:

Mitral stenosis manifests with symptoms such as exercise intolerance and nocturnal dyspnea due to elevated left atrial pressures from restricted diastolic flow through a fibrotic valve. The loud first heart sound results from the rigidity of stenotic valve leaflets, while the low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur at the apex is characteristic of turbulent flow through a narrowed mitral valve. A history of childhood rheumatic fever, a common precursor to mitral stenosis, supports this diagnosis. These clinical and historical findings align with the structural and hemodynamic changes seen in mitral stenosis.

Key learning point: Mitral stenosis, often due to rheumatic heart disease, presents with exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, a loud S1, loud P2, and a mid-diastolic rumbling murmur at the apex.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis typically presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, best heard at the right upper sternal border and radiating to the neck. The murmur described is low-pitched and rumbling, heard at the apex, which is not consistent with aortic stenosis. Additionally, aortic stenosis is more common in older patients due to calcific degeneration or in younger patients with congenital anomalies, not suggested by the patient's history.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy typically features a systolic murmur due to dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, best heard along the left sternal border with a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo quality. The described murmur is low-pitched and rumbling at the apex, inconsistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The history of a febrile illness in childhood suggests a post-inflammatory process rather than a genetic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening fatigue and shortness of breath for the past 7 months. She emigrated from China 2 years ago. Cardiac examination shows a loud S1. Which of the following contributes most to this auscultation finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve opening can be affected in patients with rheumatic heart disease as a result of tricuspid stenosis (TS). However, in the case of TS, tricuspid valve opening would be associated with an opening snap, which is distinct from the S1 heard during early diastole (i.e., immediately after S2). The closure rather than the opening of the tricuspid valve contributes to S1. Tricuspid valve closure in patients with TS can cause a loud S1, as seen here, but TS would cause features of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, ascites) rather than those of left heart failure (e.g., dyspnea).

B) CORRECT:

The first heart sound (S1) is a physiological sound created by the closure of the mitral valve and tricuspid valve that occurs at the onset of isovolumetric ventricular contraction, when ventricular pressure exceeds atrial pressure. S1 is best heard in the 5th left intercostal space in the midclavicular line (cardiac apex). In patients with mitral stenosis (MS) and mobile leaflets (i.e., in mild to moderate MS), a loud S1 is often present because the increased left atrial pressure moves the mitral leaflets further apart during diastole so that the leaflets snap shut with a greater velocity at the start of ventricular systole. If the leaflets are immobile (e.g., in severe MS) or if the leaflets fail to close completely (e.g., in mitral regurgitation), S1 would be soft. In the US, rheumatic heart disease is the most common cause of mitral stenosis in patients that have recently migrated from a developing country.

MS is associated with other auscultatory findings such as an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation. However, as MS progresses, left atrial pressure increases and causes the opening snap to occur earlier in the cardiac cycle. If atrial fibrillation develops in a patient with MS, the presystolic accentuation of the murmur will be absent.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
12: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
23: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
34: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
41: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve closure can be affected in patients with rheumatic heart disease as a result of aortic stenosis, which would also cause fatigue and dyspnea, as seen here. However, aortic valve closure generates the A2 component of S2, and patients with aortic stenosis would typically have a soft S2 (due to immobile atrial valve leaflets) and/or paradoxical splitting of S2. Aortic valve closure does not contribute towards the generation of S1.
Image Description:

If the aortic and pulmonary valves do not close simultaneously, splitting of S2 can be heard on auscultation.

Types of split:
(A) Physiological split
(B) Wide split
(C) Fixed split
(D) Paradoxical (reversed) split

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

D) INCORRECT:

Late diastolic contraction of the atria (atrial kick) against a stiff, noncompliant ventricle can cause S4. This auscultatory finding can be seen in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can present in young adults with worsening fatigue and dyspnea, as seen here. However, atrial contraction is not responsible for the generation of S1.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
12: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
23: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
34: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
41: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

E) INCORRECT:

The opening of a stiff pulmonary valve is responsible for a pulmonary valve ejection click, which can be heard in patients with mild or moderate pulmonary stenosis (PS). However, a pulmonary valve ejection click is heard during early systole (i.e., immediately after S1); pulmonary valve closure does not contribute to the generation of S1. Moreover, PS is typically encountered among pediatric patients with other congenital heart diseases (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot).
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound

F) INCORRECT:

Rapid ventricular filling, which occurs during early diastole, can generate S3if the ventricular filling pressure is increased (e.g., mitral regurgitation, heart failure) or if the ventricles are dilated (e.g., dilated cardiomyopathy). However, ventricular filling itself does not significantly increase ventricular pressure, so it does not contribute to the generation of S1. Rather, isovolumetric ventricular contraction, which causes ventricular pressure to surpass atrial pressure, leads to the event that generates S1.

Cardiac pressure-volume loops with examples of changes seen during increased contractility, preload, and afterload.
questions.hint: Worsening fatigue and dyspnea with a loud S1 in a young individual who recently immigrated from a developing country raises concern for a sequela of rheumatic heart disease.
